text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
4.31.3.1.7 - Related Resources. Revised to add a reference to the Partnership Knowledge remove the reference to the TEFRA website.
IRM 4.31.3.2 - Overview section. Removed reference to Form 5546, Examination Return Charge since it is mentioned elsewhere.
4.31.3.2.2 - TEFRA Corporate Data Initiative (CDI) Application. Removed text regarding some and paragraph (3) regarding PCS redesign.

IRM 4.31.3.3 - Screening Incoming Mail. Removed the note from paragraph (3)(a) regarding Forms 870-P and 870-L as they are no longer relevant and reference to Form 6657 in paragraph (3)(j) as it no longer used for TEFRA cases.

IRM 4.31.3.4.2 - Linking Partners. Removed the reference in paragraph (4) checking the CDI TEFRA application large case box as it no longer applies. Added a note in paragraph (13) regarding using AM424 to establish AIMS rather than CC TSLOD to allow an electronic blocking closure.

IRM 4.31.3.4.2.5 - TE/GE Partners. Added new paragraph (2) deﬁning Exempt Organizations and Employee plans. Removed prior paragraph (3) regarding preparing Form 5666, Specialist referral as that applies to the ﬁeld examiners. Removed the requirement in (4) to send a listing to TE/GE monthly and replaced with sending Schedule K-1 to designated Point of Contact.
IRM 4.31.3.4.2.6 - Linking Partners to Returns that are in Appeals. Corrected reference, PCS CTF Indicator was incorrectly referred to as the CPF Indicator. Added reference to PCS 4.4 statute report.
IRM 4.31.3.4.2.9 - Non Filers. Added clarifying text regarding when IRC 6229 extends the statute.
IRM 4.31.3.4.2.14 - Linking Returns Where there is a Technical Termination in the Same Month. Add clarifying instructions to paragraph (1) if only examining the short period return.

IRM 4.31.3.4.4 - Key Case Reports. Changed requirement for PCS Report 22-3 to be worked quarterly rather than weekly. Updated paragraph (2) retention period to be 90 days rather than 60 which was incorrect. Added paragraph (4) IRM PCS report reference.
IRM 4.31.3.5 - CPF Partner Procedures. Revised section to include information speciﬁc to paper or electronic return requests. Moved IRM 4.31.3.5.10 (1) to this section and revised to add clarity.

IRM 4.31.3.5.1 - CPF Employee Group Codes (EGCs). Removed reference to EGC 5700-5799 for Pre Filing Notiﬁcation (PFN). Revised paragraph (5) to reference BBA Chapter 2/2A. Corrected EGC 5815 to be for Exhausted BMF Partners.

IRM 4.31.3.5.2 - Returns Controlled Outside the CPF. Changed title from Return Charge-Out Documents to Returns Controlled Outside the CPF to better describe the content. Revised throughout section to distinguish tasks for paper or electronically ﬁled returns. Removed references to Form 5546 in paragraphs (1) - (3) and added reference to using EGCs 57XX. Moved IRM 4.31.3.5.10 (2) to the section and revised to add clarity.
IRM 4.31.3.5.3 - Distributing Schedules K-1. Added instruction to paragraph (2) on where the Form 6658 should be ﬁled.
IRM 4.31.3.5.4 - Receipt of Schedules K-1 From Another Campus. Removed (2) requirement to update the database, which was an error and added requirement to notate the case history of K-1 receipt.

IRM 4.31.3.5.5 - Case Building of Material Partner Returns. To paragraph (1) added (e)-(g) for additional items to be kept with case ﬁle. Removed paragraphs (4) and (5) because securing returns within the 26-27 month examination cycle is no longer possible for TEFRA partners.
IRM 4.31.3.5.5.4 - Unperfected but Exhausted. Added EGC 5814 as another EGC for an exhausted partner.
IRM 4.31.3.5.5.4 - Unperfected but Exhausted. Added EGC 5814 as another EGC for an exhausted
IRM 4.31.3.5.7.1 - Case Set up. Removed PICF 0 or blank and replaced with carryover or carryback to create more clarity.
IRM 4.31.3.5.7.1 - Case Set up. Removed PICF 0 or blank and replaced with carryover or carryback
IRM 4.31.3.5.7.1.1 - Foldering Paper Case Files. Removed subsection, because references to Form 4607 and Form 12600 are obsolete the remaining information is in IRM 4.31.3.5 and does not need

IRM 4.31.3.5.8 - Passing Through Adjustments to the Related Partner Returns. Revised paragraph (2) for tiering and (3) for multiple linkages. Moved information previously in paragraph (3) to new paragraph (4). Added new paragraph (5) to include directions on sending Form 14671. Added paragraph (6) on the acknowledgement of Form 14671.

IRM 4.31.3.5.8.1 - TEFRA Partnership Examination With Unresolved SB/SE Partner Examination. Changed the title of the subsection from ILSC to SB/SE and revised the sub-section and paragraphs to give instruction speciﬁc to SB/SE partner examinations.
IRM 4.31.3.5.9.1 - Field Suspense of SB/SE Partners. Removed paragraphs (3) and (4) because they were not relevant to SB/SE ﬁeld cases.

IRM 4.31.3.5.9.2 - Field Suspense of LB&I Partners. Added reference for Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) corporations throughout. Removed paragraph (4) and instructed employees to follow the guidance in IRM 4.31.3.5.8.3.

IRM 4.31.3.5.10 - Follow-Up Procedures for Returns. Moved the content in paragraph (1) to 4.31.3.5.2 and paragraph (2) to 4.31.3.5.4. Added new paragraph (1) and (2) regarding the need for follow up actions and monitoring incomplete ﬁles.
IRM 4.31.3.5.13.1 - Electing Large Partnership (ELP). Removed paragraph (2), this reference is for the ﬁeld examiner not the CPF. Revised paragraph (3) to establish PCS linkages per build out.

IRM 4.31.3.5.14 - Responding to Field Requests for Returns. Revised paragraph (1) to include the requirement and proper use of Form 15277 and instructions. Added AIMS transfer information to ensure AIMS status and EGC are updated properly. (2) Removed the requirement for Form 3210, this is not necessary with Form 15277. To paragraph (4) added IRM reference for Blue Ribbon copies.
IRM 4.31.3.5.18 - PCS 4-4 Report. Updated paragraph (4) to show it is the PCS Coordinator who sends the report out and corrected the timeframe from monthly to weekly.

IRM 4.31.3.5.20 - Power of Attorney (POA) for Partners in a TEFRA Partnership. Revised paragraph (4) to add better instructions for retaining the Form 2848 with TEFRA language. Other modiﬁcations throughout.

IRM 4.31.3.6.1 - Settlement Agreements Secured on District Court or Court of Federal Claims Cases. Added paragraph (3) to site the authority for partner settlement agreements. Added a reference to paragraph (2)(h) for managerial approval of penalties
4.31.3.6.2 - Processing of 60 day Letter. Revised sentences throughout to add clarity.
IRM 4.31.3.6.6 - FPAA. Revised sentence throughout to add clarity. Added a reference to paragraph (2)(j) to include penalties and managerial approval of penalties.

IRM 4.31.3.7.1 - FPAA Default. Modiﬁed paragraph (3) for clarity. Removed paragraphs (4) to (9) because information was referred to in other places of this IRM. Added a new paragraph (4) about forwarding information to the partners and suspending key case ﬁle.
IRM 4.31.3.7.2.2 - Tax Court Decision Appealed. New
IRM 4.31.3.7.2.3 - Petitioned District Court and Court of Federal Claims Cases. Modiﬁed throughout to add addition clarity and remove redundant content.
IRM 4.31.3.7.3.5 - Settlement Agreements Received as a Result of Appeals Letters. Modiﬁed all paragraphs to add clarity.

IRM 4.31.3.7.3.6 - Settlement Agreements in Docketed Cases. Added clarifying instructions to paragraph (1) and added a reference to 4.31.3.7.3.5(4) for processing instructions. Removed reference to TMP notiﬁcation that is not necessary.

IRM 4.31.3.8.1 - Refund Letters 4505-A and 4505-E. Removed the reference to Letter 4505 which has been obsoleted and replaced the correct reference either Letter 4505-A or 4505-E. Moved the note in paragraph (4) to the body of paragraph (4).
4.31.3.8.1.1 - Letter 4505-A, Notiﬁcation of Potential Refunds Resulting from a Partnership paragraph (1) that the letter goes to the TMP of the Partnership.

IRM 4.31.3.8.1.2 - Letter 4505-E, Notiﬁcation of Potential Refunds Resulting from a Partnership Exam. Added to paragraph (1) the requirement to send Form 886-A so partnership knows their of the adjustment. Added to paragraph (4) that letters do not need to be sent to all tier partnerships.
IRM 4.31.3.9 - H Freeze Release. Added a note to paragraph (1) on what closing packages should not have the H Freeze released.

IRM 4.31.3.13.4.3 - Check for Penalties and Affected Items. Removed paragraph (1) reference to penalty application prior to August 5, 1997, as this is no longer relevant and reference to Letter 3219 which is no longer used for TEFRA cases. Added new note to paragraph (1) regarding if a pass-through entity signs page 2, of Form 870-LT.

IRM 4.31.3.13.5 - Tier Report Writing. Modiﬁcations throughout to add clarity. In paragraph (3) removed the reference to Form 4318 as only the Form 4700-T should be used. Moved the note in paragraph (6) to new paragraph (6)(e).

IRM 4.31.3.13.5.1 - Tier Partners Requesting Partnership Level Assessments. Added to paragraph (1) tier partnership AIMS must be transferred to ﬁeld examiner or appeals officer and H freeze is added to prevent closure. Added instructions to (4) on receiving a Form 906 Tier closing package.

IRM 4.31.3.13.6.1 - Determining Adjustments. Removed the reference to penalties in paragraph (4) and added affected items and carryover from a prior year. Removed paragraph (6) as the ARDI was retired in 2001 and replaced by Unpaid Assessments which are not considered by the CPF.

IRM 4.31.3.13.6.3 - Examination Report with Affected Items or Partner Level Penalties. Changed the reference to Letter 525 in paragraphs (2) & (5) to 525-D, a new 30 day letter speciﬁc to pass-through examinations. Changed the reference from Letter 3219 to Letter 531 for Notice of Deﬁciency since recent revision to Letter 3219 will not work for TEFRA cases.
4.31.3.13.6.5 - IRC Section 6404(g), Suspension of Interest and Certain Penalties. Added (10) to reference IRM 20.2.5.7 and the need to do May/Sequa calculations.

IRM 4.31.3.13.6.6 - Completion of Workpapers. Modiﬁed the entire section to add clarity and bullet list of required entries. Removed the references to IRMs 4.10.9 and 4.19.13 which are used by ﬁeld examiners and did not provide the speciﬁcs needed for TEFRA pass-through adjustments.

IRM 4.31.3.13.8.1 - Case File Assembly. Added new paragraph (3) to explain when to use the electronic closure blocking code. Added new paragraph (4) which gives instructions if the TE is unable to close using electronic blocking code.
IRM 4.31.3.13.8.1.1 - Streamlined No Change Closures. Modiﬁed throughout to allow for electronic case ﬁles rather than just paper.

IRM 4.31.3.13.9 - TEFRA Assessment Prior to Partnership Examination Closing. Revised paragraph (1) and added new paragraph (2) to refer to revised sections IRM 4.31.3.5.8.1 and 4.31.3.5.8.2. Added a note to paragraph (2) as a reminder to coordinate with the ﬁeld examiner or appeals officer if preparing a report when the case is not controlled by the CPF.
IRM 4.31.3.13.9.1 - TEFRA Partners in SB/SE, W&I, or Appeals. The material relating to partner examinations was moved to IRM 4.31.3.5.8.1 so it was all in one section and not repeated.

IRM 4.31.3.13.13 - No Change Partner Returns. Revised paragraph (3) if there was a prior adjustment the partner can’t be closed with a DC 02. Removed the note from paragraph (3) and created a new paragraph (4).

IRM 4.31.3.13.18.1 - Reports. Modiﬁcations in paragraphs (1) - (3) to add clarity. Change paragraph (3) (a) to new paragraph (4). Removed paragraph (3) (b) - (d) because they were not report related. Added new paragraphs (5) - (13) to list speciﬁc reports and their function. Added table with information on ORCAS data.
IRM 4.31.3.14 - Key Case Administrative File Suspense. Added new paragraph (2) on electronic key case administrative ﬁle in RGS and when it can be archived.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum SBSE-01-1021-0051, Handling of the qualiﬁed business income deduction on investor returns controlled by examination ﬁeld support groups in LB&I and SB/SE Campus; IPU 22U0881 TEFRA Examinations - CPF Procedures. IRM 4.31.3, Pass-Through Entity Handbook, TEFRA Examinations - CPF Procedures, dated 04-10-2019, (effective MM-DD-YYYY) is superseded.

) TEFRA was passed in

to allow examinations and statutes to be con- trolled at the partnership level. This eliminated the need to control each individual partner statute. It also uniﬁed the litigation process whereby the matters partner (TMP) or a notice partner may commence such litigation at partnership level by ﬁling a petition rather than each individual partner. The PCS was created to establish an electronic linkage between the and their underlying partners. This helps ensure that partners, no matter complex the partnership structure, are issued notices and adjusted in a manner. PCS linkage allows the campus to work the partners so can focus on partnership examinations. PCS also allows the campus to temically generate notices, control statutes, and gather closing information. (

The number of one-year assessment statute dates are monitored to determine if the closure goal is attainable, or if it needs to be increased.
There are several terms unique to TEFRA. Examples of these terms:
Deﬁned Terms and Acronyms

Deﬁnition Administrative Adjustment Request (AAR) - Notiﬁ- cation to the IRS of any subsequent change by a TMP or partner, to the treatment of a partnership item. The AAR is ﬁled by checking the appropriate boxes on Form
X, Amended Partnership Return, or by submitting Form
(partnership level), Notice of Inconsistent Treatment or Admin- istrative Adjustment Request (AAR), along with a claim for refund or an amended return. AAR pro- cedures are in IRM

Statute AC is the alpha code used when a TEFRA part- nership statute will be controlled at the partner level. This keeps the partnership from showing as an expired statute on statute reports. It also helps identify when the statute is being controlled at the partner level.
AC is the alpha code used when a TEFRA part

nership statute will be controlled at the partner level. This keeps the partnership from showing as an expired statute on statute reports. It also helps identify when the statute is being controlled at the partner level.
Centralized Case Processing (CCP) - This function processes assessments and abatements and closes or transfers cases from the area to the campus or to ﬁles.

Campus Pass-through Function (CPF) - The CPF is the suspense unit for investor returns located in the Brookhaven and Ogden campuses. The two CPFs will be maintained to obtain and control, through the AIMS and Partnership Control System (PCS), any partner, shareholder or investor returns related to key cases within their jurisdic- tion. Term Deﬁnition FPAA Notice of Final Partnership Administrative Adjust- ment (FPAA) - The statutory notice of adjustments (as distinguished from a statutory notice of deﬁ- ciency) in a partnership proceeding that is subject to judicial review if a petition is ﬁled under Internal Revenue Code (IRC)

in the Tax Court, the Court of Federal Claims, or the District Court of the United States where the partnership’s principal place of business is located. Only partnership ad- justments are identiﬁed. An FPAA may also include penalties the applicability of which is de- termined at the partnership level. FPAAs should only be issued by the Technical Services Pass- Through Coordinator or the CPF, and not ﬁeld agents. IAT Integrated Automation Technologies (IAT). IAT provides tools to IRS employees that simplify research, reduce keystrokes and increase the accuracy of regular work processes. ) PCS is the system of record for controlling pass-through returns. The PCS database establishes an electronic linkage between a pass-through and all partners linked to it. This linkage ensures the correct partners are properly provided notices and allows the campus to monitor statutes unique to Statutorily required TEFRA notices are systemically generated through as well as mailing lists. The system also generates several static inventory statute reports. All returns assigned to the campus TEFRA program must be linked on PCS if possible. (

Examinations - CPF Procedures 4.31.3
Employees must use the Integrated Automation Technologies (IAT) tools in Exhibit

whenever possible. The use of some of the tools is mandatory when applicable for use. The IAT tools simplify processing by assisting the user with IDRS research and input. The tools reduce the chance of errors and improve productivity. They are desktop productivity enhancing tools. The IAT Web site should be check periodically for new tools that may assist in processing cases. Descriptions of each tool as well as job aids for each tool can be found on the web site.

Generally, taxable amended returns that address TEFRA issues related to open key case examination should not be assessed before the proceedings are completed. However, if the taxable amended return is accompanied by payment, the assessment should be made. A “deﬁciency” does not include amounts paid (i.e., amounts “collected without assessment”). IRC

)(B). A “deﬁciency” also does not include amounts shown on the payer’s return. “Return” for this purpose includes an amended return, the amended return indicates that the amounts are disputed. Treas. Reg.

(a) (last sentence). The payment eliminates the deﬁciency. If there is any possibility that the “payment” can be construed as merely a “deposit” rather than a payment, or if the amended return indicates that the additional amount is being disputed, then the assessment cannot be made until the TEFRA proceeding is complete. Taxable amended returns that do not address any TEFRA issues should be assessed. These should be assessed by the area that received them. ) There are two different types of untimely notice procedures. a. The TEFRA proceedings are still ongoing, or b. The TEFRA proceedings are complete. (
) An untimely notice when the proceedings are still ongoing can occur when there is less than
days on the partnership statute and the ﬁeld wants to begin an examination. This requires the NBAP, FPAA and Letter
, Untimely Notice Letter (TEFRA Proceedings Ongoing), to be issued at the same time. It is possible to have this situation if a partner was inadvertently sent an FPAA within
days of the TMP FPAA. In this instance, the partner FPAA and the Letter
should be sent together. (
) The Letter

notiﬁes the partner of the untimely notice and provides an opportunity to a. elect to have their partnership items treated as nonpartnership items, b. elect to have any prior settlement agreement apply to them (
) The election must be ﬁled within
days from the date they received their FPAA. The election must be completed as explained within the Letter
) If no election is ﬁled, the partner will remain part of the TEFRA (

) If an election is ﬁled, the one-year assessment period will begin on the date the FPAA was mailed to the partner. The TEFRA indicator needs to be removed from PCS. A statutory notice of deﬁciency must be issued and assessed during the one year period. When the statutory notice is issued Report Package Indicator needs to be updated to “S”. (

) An untimely notice when the proceedings are complete can occur when a partner wasn’t provided an FPAA on a case that got petitioned. After the decision is entered, but before the expiration of the OYD we discover that FPAA was issued. This requires the FPAA and Letter
, Untimely Notice Letter (TEFRA Proceedings Complete), be issued at the same time. (
) The Letter

notiﬁes the partner of the untimely notice and provides the opportunity to ﬁle an election to have their partnership items treated according to: a. the FPAA, b. a ﬁnal court decision, or c. a prior settlement agreement (

) By appealing the Tax Court decision, the case is like a refund litigation case that the partners are looking to reduce or eliminate a Tax Court decision that increases the partner’s tax liability. The key case and partner cases remain open pending the resolution of the appeal process. (

The simplest way to compute a one-year date (if the start of the one-year does not occur on the same day as the ﬁnal determination or conversion) use Julian dates. The date of the event is converted to a Julian date. The propriate waiting period is added to the Julian date of the event. This new Julian date is converted back to a calendar date. This is the start date. The one-year date is one year after this start date. As a matter of practice, the campuses will subtract one day from the true one-year date when the one-year date is entered on the PCS. All partners below the key case being closed DC 02 should be closed DC 02 as well, given no other linkages exist or prior partials were processed. 03 - Agreed Before 60 Day Letter Used when agreements are secured after the closing confer- ence and before issuance of a 60 day letter or an FPAA. 04 - Agreed After the 60 Day Used for 1998 and subsequent Letter or Appeals Settlement TEFRA agreed cases (with or Letter without penalties) with an agreement date. 08 - Other Used for 1997 and prior TEFRA agreed cases (with or without penalties). Disposal Code When to use the disposal code. 31 - Survey Before Assignment May be used under speciﬁc cir- cumstances with HQ approval. Generally, this disposal code should only be used when closing returns that should never have been brought into the campus inventory. Consult with HQ regarding the circumstance for using this disposal code and secure their agreement before closing any returns. Cases closed using this disposal code will not count as a closure. 32 - Survey After Assignment Used with carryback/carryover years where the return was ordered in for potential issues, but was not needed. For example, if a return was needed to determine the amount of a car- ryforward adjustment impacting a later year, but not impacting that return, the return should be closed DC 01. DC 32 should only be used only if no analysis of the return was conducted. If the IRC 6501 has insufficient time remaining to allow an adjustment to be made, or the IRC 6501 has expired, the Extended to Date should reﬂect the one-year assessment date. Use the later of the one-year date or IRC 6501 date. NEVER shorten the taxpayer’s ASED. Partial Closure On partial assessments, after the partial closure has been completed, the statute date on AIMS must be corrected to the original date. If the statute date on AIMS contains alpha charac- ters in the statute date, such as BB, DD, or HH, that date must be updated to the one-year assess- ment statute date in order to input the adjustment. ORCAS Reports

This report contains all cases controlled to an IDRS employee number and can be used to: a. Identify cases requiring action. b. Identify speciﬁc cases for review. c. Monitor the size of the employees’ inventories. d. Determine if employees are working inventory in the proper order. e. Set closure expectations. f. Identify potential management problem cases. g. Monitor statutes. This report is available on the ORCAS delivery database and on

e. Set closure expectations. f. Identify potential management problem cases. g. Monitor statutes. This report is available on the ORCAS delivery database and on Control-D every Monday morning, Report Name: “Overage Report”, Job Name: CCA

The CCA report will be generated by the managers. Employees may also have access to generate their own reports for cases assigned to them (local option), Items on the Report - For each case shown, the following information is provided: a. TIN - Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number b. IRS Rcd Date - The date IRS received the case c. Status - Case History Status Code (A - Active, B- Background, C - Closed, M - Other long term delay, and S - Suspense) d. Category - Category of case e. Freeze Codes - Freeze Codes on the IDRS account f. MFT - Master File Tax g. Mod Per - Tax Period on assigned account h. Assigned Date - The date the case was assigned to a tax examiner i. Activity Code - A

character ﬁeld on IDRS the tax examiner uses to enter actions taken on the case j. Name Ctrl - Name Control on taxpayer’s account k. Action Date - Date of last action input on the account l. Age - Number of days case has aged on IDRS m. MF Mod Balance - Module Balance on IDRS n. ORCAS Reports Manager/Lead will provide the tax examiner with the page(s) of the report where the cases are controlled to their IDRS number. Tax examiner will notate the actions taken on each case worked and any updates on an added comment section. The report should be returned to the Manager/Lead by the end of employee’s work week. Tax examiners must work cases in the following priority order: a. Cases controlled using Category Code NLUN. b. Cases with an ASED expiring within

days. c. Cases where the taxpayer was contacted and the suspense has expired. d. Cases with mismatched (erroneous) case controls, Category Codes, and/or Activity Codes. e. Remaining cases in oldest IRS received date order. The Manager/Lead must also review the inventory on a weekly basis to ensure cases are being pulled and worked in statute date order. This review must include the following items: a. Compare the previous week’s listing to the current week’s and determine if cases or batches are being pulled in statute date order. b. Identify any TINs that were not pulled in statute date order. c. Attempt to physically locate the case(s). If located, assign the case(s) to a TE to be worked. d. Control the TINs of any missing cases to a TE to recreate the case ﬁle using electronic data or corresponding with the taxpayer. The Manager/Lead will provide an annotated aged/ORCAS listing to the Department Manager each week and provide a list of TINs that were identiﬁed as not being worked in EGC age order as well as statute priority. These reports should be maintained for two months.
